10038.description: American Youth Table Tennis seeks interested college students in the New York City Metro Area to teach high school students the sport of table tennis, leadership, fair play, respect and teamwork. Table Tennis expertise required. As a volunteer coach you will receive a small per visit stipend per visit to cover transportation costs and effort. We will assign you to a New York City High School Table Tennis Program as an Assistant Table Tennis Coach. Duties will include, teaching basic and intermediate table tennis - footwork, serve, serve return, backhand, forehand, tactics, loop, loop drive as well as serving multi-ball and providing a positive and exciting framework for play, and dialog. American Youth Table Tennis and New York City Department of Education have teamed up to make this opportunity available to you. Table Tennis is an official varsity sport in New York City. We will be accepting applications in November and through to the end of January. We are in need of expert collegiate table tennis players to assist in selected High School Programs for the 2017-18 season which begins in December and Continues through March 2018 As an Assistant Coach, you will be giving back to the New York City community by imparting your table tennis knowledge on receptive and interested high school students. This program will look good on your resume and will help the next generation of collegiate table tennis players.
10038.title: Youth Table Tennis Coach - Collegiate Internship Program

10038.description: Mentor a 13-18 year old student to provide guidance and broaden his or her horizons. Help a student grow to be confident, caring young adult by becoming a role model and someone he or she can rely on. Mentors and mentees are matched after carefully considering the goals of the mentee and what the mentor can do to support that goal. We are currently looking for more male mentors. The mentoring program is for males and females, but as of now, we do not have enough male mentors.
10038.title: Middle School/High School Mentor (male)

10038.description: Teach 4th and 5th graders the fundamentals of basketball and what teamwork really is. Coach the students and help them win games against other schools by guiding them through the seasons. Be the one to show the young students the love for the game.
10038.title: Volunteer Basketball Coaches Needed

10038.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10038.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 126 Jacob August Riis, Manhattan)

10038.description: We are looking for volunteers with dance experience to help run a weekly movement-based creative workshop for students with intellectual disabilities in Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, Wednesdays from 11-12. This opportunity takes place over 12 weeks, for a small group of middle and high school students. The workshop will culminate with an informal showing. We are also looking for volunteer yoga instructors in all boroughs.
10038.title: Looking for Dance Teachers and Yoga Instructors

10118.description: Join us to help rescue leftovers from a cafeteria in the Empire State Building! This event will end at BRC, located at 127 W 25th St, New York, NY 10001. Medium to heavy weight - the average amount of food rescued from this event is 35-65 pounds.
10118.title: End Food Waste in Midtown Fridays at 3PM!

10013.description: Are you a professional looking to give back to your community? Would you like to help teenagers learn how to become a successful professional? Chelsea CTE High School is hosting our annual Career Day on Wednesday, March 28th and we are looking for professionals from all fields to come speak to our students about their careers. Come present to a classroom of students for twenty-two minute sessions twice in 1-period or spend part of the day speaking to various groups of students. We have seven convenient time slots available. We will work around your schedule. Your participation will make a lasting impression on students on how they can achieve their career goals. Time slots available for Career Presentations - Please choose which time slots fit your schedule best. Period 2 - 9:03-9:48 * Period 3- 9:51-10:36 * Period 4- 10:39-11:24 Period 5-11:27-12:12 * Period 6- 12:15-1:00 * Period 7- 1:03-1:48 * Period 8- 1:50-2:35 If you have any questions, please feel free to email me at tpoon@chelseahs.org
10013.title: Career Day Guest Speaker Opportunity
10013.org: Chelsea Career And Technical Education High School

10013.description: Every summer CMP acts as an official provider for the Summer Youth Employment Program (SYEP), a program that connects youth aged 16-24 to employment opportunities across the city. This summer CMP is expected to assist 700 youth in gaining work experience, developing their financial literacy and exploring future careers. You can learn more about the program here: http://www1.nyc.gov/site/dycd/index.pageThis service opportunity will help summer job-seeking youth in filling out the SYEP Application interviewing them and helping them a select an ideal work site where they can learn and grow. Responsibilities Attend volunteer orientation and learn about the enrollment process. Develop an understanding of assigned participating work sites. Get to know the candidates educational background, career goals and interests. Match candidates to an appropriate work site. Qualifications: Strong communication skills. Organized and can complete enrollment process in a timely manner. Previous experience working with young adults is a plus. Time frame: Tentative Dates: first two weekends of April 4/7, 4/8, 4/14 and 4/15 Time: 9am-5pm Dates and times are flexible based on the volunteer’s availability. Benefits: Free lunch provided on day of enrollment. Opportunity to give back to the community and make professional connections.
10013.title: SYEP Job Interviewer

10013.description: For many new immigrants, learning English is a first step to full participation in American society. Help them take that first step by becoming a volunteer teacher in English or Citizenship classes. English classes help students improve their communication skills. Citizenship classes help students prepare for the U.S. citizenship test. Volunteers work in teams to plan lessons and teach the class. This fun and rewarding experience gives you a chance to make a difference in the lives of others. Individuals with an interest in education careers are encouraged to apply. Requirements Must have good communication skills and a strong desire to help and work with new immigrants Prior teaching experience is preferred. Bilingual skills are a plus. We prefer volunteers who can commit to teaching at least two semesters Prospective volunteers must complete application and be interviewed. Volunteer Schedule: 9:30 am-11:30am (Tues or Thurs) 10:30 am-12:30 pm (Tues or Thurs) 1pm to 4pm (Saturday) 6:30pm to 8:30 pm (Mon, Tues or Wed) Spring 2018 - February 27, 2018 to June 7, 2018 Summer 2018 - July 9, 2018 to August 18, 2018 Prospective volunteers must complete application and will be interviewed. Please contact us at cpanyc@cpanyc.org for an application OR apply on-line here: http://bit.ly/volunteerteacherapp For more information: http://bit.ly/VolunteerToTeachEnglishorCitizenshipClass
10013.title: Teach English or Citizenship Class in Chinatown

10013.description: Help rescue catered lunch leftovers from 2 offices in Greenwich Village! We will deliver the food to NYC Rescue Mission, located at 90 Lafayette St, New York, NY 10013. Mediumweight: the average amount of food rescued from this event is 25-50 pounds.
10013.title: Fight Food Waste in Greenwich on Fridays 3:30PM!

10013.description: VOLUNTEER NEEDED FOR OUR MANHATTAN OFFICE INSIDE OF FEDCAP. DUTIES: --Greet the client --Explain that we take pictures and they have to sign a waiver [(we can cut their heads off on the picture, should they not want to be seen) Not mandatory for receiving services] --Measure assist them in tying a tie (if they do not know how) finding a suit, shirt, slacks, shoes, etc. that fits. (They can try on the clothing in the restroom.) --Arrange for the hemming of pants or the sewing on of buttons with the tailor and set a date for the client to pick up the tailored items. If no alterations are needed, then fold up the items and place in a bag for the client. --Keep records of activities and calls in the log. --Be able to work alone, with minimal supervision or with others We are doing one day a week, for now (date to be discussed), but the time will be 10 AM to 3 PM. This is a great opportunity for anyone wanting to go into law enforcement and who wants to see \"the other side\" after a person comes home, someone that wants to be in the fashion industry, or social services/non-profit sector. You will be networking with everyday people, politicians, individuals from different programs (formerly incarcerated individuals, etc.), City organizations/programs, and pastors. There is a possibility that you will be helping with administrative work and our events as well. You must be neat and presentable. We also will need you to assist in pop-up shops and the occasional donation pick up. Check out what we do to get a better feel for 100 Suits http://www.100suits.org/100-suits-speaks Please be reliable! SERIOUS INQUIRIES ONLY!!!
10013.title: Fashion and Justice Volunteer (Queens)

10013.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premier human services providers, is a 123-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. Our Senior Center at East 54th Street and Lexington Avenue is a vibrant program that provides hundreds of older adults with educational, cultural, health and social activities every week. We are seeking instructors for a variety of classes and activities including: Zumba Chair Yoga Mah Jong Line Dancing Conversational Italian Book Discussion Group Digital Photography Instructors lead their respective classes/activities once per week on weekdays. If you have one of the skills above and are interested in sharing your time and knowledge with active and enthusiastic older adults please contact Anthony Snowden, Volunteer Director at asnowden@lenoxhill.org or 212-218-0487.
10013.title: Instructor for Senior Center

10012.description: There’s never a dull moment here at Housing Works, between our annual benefits such as Design on a Dime, weekly Thrift Shop sales, and a wide array of events at our beloved Bookstore Cafe - we have a plethora of exciting and unique happenings to keep you busy all year long! Many of these events need extra support, including our annual Best of Spring sale. Volunteers will have an opportunity to support our staff in set up and clean up, as well as as customers shop our best donations of the season all throughout March! Almost every one of our eleven thrift shops will be holding a Best of Spring, which means we need tons of volunteers throughout the month! This is a great opportunity for those interested in retail, sales, and fashion merchandising and is a perfect opportunity for groups up to 5 people. For more details about the event, please visit our event page: https://www.housingworks.org/events For a list of our store locations, please visit https://www.housingworks.org/businesses Email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org for more details, as there are many shifts across our shops.
10012.title: Support Housing Works at Best of Spring!

10012.description: Rescue catered leftovers from 2 offices in SoHo! This event will end at Bowery Mission, located at 227 Bowery, New York, NY 10002. Medium weight: the average amount of food rescued from this event is 30-50 pounds.
10012.title: Fight Hunger is Soho Fridays 3:30PM!

10012.description: NYU has some delicious catering every other week. We need volunteers to pick up this catering and deliver it to a nearby shelter. Heavy pickup: 15-90 pounds
10012.title: Assist NYU in the Fight Against Food Waste Fridays 3:30PM!

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our organization. For more information about our mission and programs, visit our website: www.housingworks.org We are looking for one individual to support our volunteer coordinator in volunteer recruitment, management, and training. Be a part of one of Housing Works' biggest fundraising events of the year, Design on a Dime, while improving your administrative skills and supporting our volunteer recruitment efforts! The individual will support the volunteer coordinator by doing the following: Researching and recruiting groups and individuals that may be interested in volunteering at our annual Design on a Dime Basic data entry (Salesforce CRM) Answering emails and calls professionally and promptly Administrative task as needed Committing to about 5-10 hours a week Must be available to provide support the final week of April If interested, please email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org with \"Data Entry Volunteer\" as subject line. Please include resume as an attachment. You must send an email to be considered; requests via VolunteerMatch will not be accepted. Must be 18 or older.
10012.title: Volunteer Recruitment Opportunity!

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our organization. For more information about our mission and programs, visit our website: www.housingworks.org Be a part of one of Housing Works' biggest fundraising events of the year, Design on a Dime while improving your administrative skills and gaining customer service experience! Responsibilities and Duties Researching and making outgoing donation and/or cold calls to obtain products for upcoming event Basic data entry (Salesforce CRM) Answering emails and calls professionally and promptly Administrative task as needed Excellent phone and computer skills a plus. If interested, please email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org with \"Data Entry Volunteer\" as subject line. Please include resume as an attachment.
10012.title: Design on a Dime Data Entry Volunteer

10011.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our non-profit organization. By volunteering, you are directly responsible for providing funding to and advocating for New Yorkers affected by homelessness and HIV/AIDS. Thank you for your interest in volunteering at Design on a Dime 2018! Each year, DOD depends on the hard work of hundreds of volunteers. You can volunteer to help in many ways, including event setup, sales and breakdown. This is a great opportunity for individuals looking to get involved with Housing Works, as well as groups looking to volunteer! Opportunities are available throughout the last week of April, with shifts in the morning, afternoon, and evening. Please email volunteer@housingworks.org for a complete schedule. All participating volunteers will receive a brand new Design on a Dime 2018 t-shirt along with a 25% discount card to be used during our Public Sale Days or at one of our Thrift Shops (valid for 30 days). If you are interested in volunteering, or would like to sign up your group to volunteer for Design on a Dime 2018 please email volunteers@housingworks.org.
10011.title: Design On a Dime 2018, Great for Groups and Individuals!

10011.description: GRANT WRITER The Grant Writer is primarily responsible for developing and writing grant proposals to foundations and other grant-making organizations, and will persuasively communicate CSP's mission and programs to potential funders. Reporting to the Executive Director, the Grant Writer will assemble and submit grant requests, establish and maintain personal contact and relationships with foundation contacts, conduct prospect research, and maintain a calendar of submissions and other deadlines. To get a response please send RESUME.
10011.title: Grant Writer

10011.description: Education Program Coordinator - Chelsea Sculpture Park. New York , New York. Basic Requirements: BA or MA in related discipline required (Art Education) Post college professional work experience required Demonstrated experience with art education or other informal art programming and curriculum design Demonstrated knowledge of Microsoft computer programs and excellent presentation skills Job Responsibilities: Coordinate and develop of new partner-institution/organization relationships and curriculum Provide leadership and direction towards the design and implementation of art educational programming and curriculum in compliance with national and state learning objectives, accreditation guidelines, and innovative art methodologies Establish and grow professional relationships with constituents, peers, associations and partner schools To Apply: Please submit your resume with cover letter and references to the contact information listed below. Set against the backdrop of the Hudson River, Chelsea Sculpture Park will offer fine art for the public to experience, up close and outdoors. The park's mission is to provide an aesthetic oasis in the Chelsea Cove section of Hudson River Park located between 22nd and 26th Streets, just steps away from the world-class Chelsea Art District. We are looking for a Education Program Coordinator to assist the founder and executive-director of Chelsea Sculpture Park develop and implement an educational program foccusing on the exhibitions of the sculpture park.
10011.title: Educational Program - Coordinator

10011.description: Chelsea Sculpture Park New York, New York Are you considering a future in arts administration, nonprofit management, fundraising, arts education or a related field? This is a great opportunity to gain experience working at a brand new nonprofit arts organization that is dedicated to building a sculpture park on the banks of the Hudson River Park. Gain invaluable insights and learn fundraising strategies as part of a dynamic Development team. Assist with prospect research, special events, direct mail, and our donor database, as well as pursue special projects. Internship credit may be arranged through your academic program. The ideal candidate will be organized and detail-oriented, and have good computer skills. Those with prospect research experience and graduate students in arts administration and arts education are especially welcome. The hours for this position are flexible within the work week. A modest stipend is available. To Apply: Please be sure to include current contact information so that we may arrange an interview. To get a response please send RESUME .
10011.title: Development Intern

10011.description: Computer/It - Tech Support - All aspects of tech support for the organization including maintenance, troubleshoot, specially ANTI-VIRUS, and optimal functioning of the system. Must have experience with Microsoft and Windows systems. To get a response please send RESUME .
10011.title: Computer support

10036.description: Come join us & volunteer with our Mailing Project! LiveOn NY is hosting their Annual Gala, and we need help mailing invitations! Folding & Stuffing Envelopes Organizing mailings by date If you available Friday, March 16 from 9 AM - 1 PM and would like to help, reach out to Victoria Thornton, 212-398-6565 ext 235 or vthornton@liveon-ny.org
10036.title: Mail Stuffing!

10036.description: Come join us as we educate children about healthy eating, food, and taste. Training Dates: Monday, February 26th, 5:30 PM Wednesday, February 28th, 12:00 PM What is Spoons Across America? Spoons Across America (SAA) is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to educating children, teachers, and families about the benefits of healthy eating though food and nutrition-based educational programs for children. What is Agriculture Literacy Week? Spoons Across America is the primary New York City implementer of Cornell Cooperative Extension’s New York Agriculture Literacy Week. In this free program for New York City schools, 1st and 2nd graders learn about New York state agriculture - what kinds of food are grown and produced in the state, and the people who are involved in growing and producing them. Spoons Across America trains volunteers to read a selected storybook and lead a related curriculum activity. Between March 12 and April 25, 2018, volunteers will read Before We Eat: From Farm to Table by Pat Brisson. Students will be taken on the journey from farm to table to understand different aspects of agriculture and the many possible careers involved. This is a captivating glimpse of what it takes to bring the food we eat to us in order to nourish our bodies and spirits. What do Volunteers do? After participating in a hands-on training, volunteers participate in and lead all aspects of Agriculture Literacy Week implementation. Volunteer responsibilities include reading the Agriculture Literacy Week book aloud to the class, leading an activity related to the book, and set up and clean up. We are looking for individuals enthusiastic about healthy eating and children’s programming to join us! Volunteer Training: All volunteers receive training at the Spoons Across America offices (630 Ninth Avenue @ 44th Street in Manhattan), and are required to attend one of the following training dates: Monday, February 26th, 5:30 PM Wednesday, February 28th, 12:00 PM **** Do you work for a business or company that wants to make a volunteer commitment? We can schedule a special training session for groups of 10 or more people, onsite or at our offices. Contact Ali for more information. When do your programs take place? Agriculture Literacy Week programs occur DURING SCHOOL HOURS. Please be advised that there are no after-work hours available for Agriculture Literacy Week. I'm ready to go! How do I sign up? If you are interested in volunteering with Spoons Across America this year, please contact Ali McDowell, Director of Programs and Partnerships, at ali@spoonsacrossamerica.org. In your email, please indicate which training session you will attend: Monday, February 26th at 5:30 PM or Wednesday, February 28th at 12:00 PM. * Please note: Volunteers must complete a background check prior to the program date.
10036.title: New York Agriculture Literacy Week - join us in the classroom!
10036.org: From Farm to Table d/b/a Spoons Across America

10036.description: At Breaking Ground, we strive to provide our clients with more than just four walls and a roof. With the full spectrum of services that our organization provides, we also offer a support system and community. It is especially important for residents who have experienced the loneliness of street homelessness, that they know that they’re now a part of an embracing community. Volunteers for this event can expect to set up the event space, serve food and drinks, but most importantly, you will engage with our residents, who we are working to build community around, while reintegrating them with the broader community as well.
10036.title: Karaoke Party at the Times Square

10036.description: Love to dance and love working with children! Seeking Intermediate level ballet teacher for an amazing group of talented 8-14yr olds. Basic knowledge of ballet technique is required. Come help teach the awesome kids of the Hell's Kitchen Community!
10036.title: Children's Ballet Teacher!

10036.description: You will have a great time meeting as many people as possible at various events and inviting them to upcoming productions that make a difference and begin crucial conversations.
10036.title: Fun social butterfly volunteering!

10036.description: The Children’s Tumor Foundation is the leading nonprofit funding source of NF (neurofibromatosis) research in the world. In a few short years, we have grown from a foundation that funds promising science to one that catalyzes the drug discovery process through a series of innovative processes, key partnerships and strategic investments. Do you enjoy helping to raise money for a good cause? We are looking for dedicated volunteers to help organize and execute our new and exciting 5K National Tour that is coming to New York on April 15, 2018! Event website: https://join.ctf.org/event/i-know-a-fighter-5k-new-york-city-2018/e158594 Volunteer Sign up: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe15fflYulmmv4CgIxi9C1FXbvei77zazstCq2436jpbzIF5Q/viewform
10036.title: New York 5K Race Event Volunteers - New York City

10036.description: We are in need of a panel of Industry experts in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering Arts, Math (STEAM) to inspire, motivate, educate students to enter these fields. You will be part of a panel of five or six people speaking about your career and how it relates to STEAM. Students will then be able to ask questions of you. You will need to commit your morning from 9-11 if selected.

10036.description: What will be expected of me as a volunteer? As a volunteer, you would be expected to help and mentor students by being interactive and supportive during the program when the students need help by having the opportunity to learn how to inspire students to be life-long learners. Some of the examples you may be assigned to do is mentoring students, registration, giving tours of the facility, setting up and cleaning up before and after the program. Do I need any special skills? No, you do not need to have any special skills. Our program incorporates a variety of team building activities that support our goal to engage students to work collaboratively. The result is that by volunteering you will benefit from the experience and come away with valuable skills. To learn more about the opportunity reach out to our team at events@we-connect-the-dots.org, to learn more about the program please visit our website at http://we-connect-the-dots.org/discoveryday2018/ Shifts: (any or all) Monday, April 16th 8:00 am - 3:30 pm Tuesday, April 17th 8:00 am - 3:30 pm Wednesday, April 18th 8:00 am - 3:30 pm
10036.title: We-Connect-the-Dots Discovery Day 2018

10031.description: The annual Face to Face conference gives participants the opportunity to think deeply and learn more about arts in education. This year’s conference will have over 40 breakout sessions where arts educators across the field can come together to share practices and network with one another, as well as celebrate the 25 th anniversary of the Roundtable! Face to Face 2018 is looking for volunteers to aid in running the conference this year. The volunteers for the conference are vital members of the team that ensure all conference goers have an enjoyable and memorable experience. Face to Face will take place at The City College of New York at Shepard Hall on Wednesday April 4 th from 7:00 am to 7:30 pm and Thursday April 5 th from 7:00 am to 6:30 pm. Volunteer hours will be broken down into two shifts over the course of each day, and volunteers are encouraged to participate for as many shifts as they are able. During both days of the conference, volunteers will be tasked with helping during registration and check-in, monitoring the coat room, managing the flow of traffic in the hallways, as well as working as assistants to the presenters during the breakout sessions and documenting the conference on social media. As volunteers for Face to Face, this is a wonderful opportunity to work with your peers, meet professionals in the field and discuss what the future of arts education can be. If you are interested in being a volunteer for the conference this year, Please click here to complete our online volunteer sign-up form. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me at jesaliski@gmail.com at any time! I hope to hear from you soon, and see you at Face to Face 2018!
10031.title: NYC Arts in Education Roundtable Face to Face Conference 2018
10031.org: THE NEW YORK CITY ARTS-IN-EDUCATION ROUNDTABLE INC

10031.description: The Boys & Girls Club of Harlem’s (BGCHarlem) mission is to provide access and opportunity for youth to reach their full potential as responsible members of the community. We believe that success is within reach of every young person that walks through our doors. Our kids benefit from trained, caring professional staff and volunteers who help them take control of their lives, envision productive futures and reach the goals. Core to this is the development of strong character and leadership skills and we seek your support to both models and encourage them as a volunteer group mentor for our Girls mentoring program. Our Girls mentoring program provides girls ages 8-17, with the skills to develop positive self-esteem, and adopt healthy lifestyle habits. Weekly participants engage in discussions on a range of topics that include media influences on females, dating relationships, and health prevention and education. Volunteers, with the support of BGCHarlem staff, will help to facilitate these discussions over a 10-week session, guiding youth through a curriculum that builds competencies in: Understanding and implementing the Boys and Girls Club of Harlem program Having in-depth and potentially uncomfortable conversations about challenges facing teens today Discussing nutrition, cooking and maintaining a healthy lifestyle. Our Boys Mentoring program uses interactive activities to educate males 8-12 and 13-17 on the critical issues that young men face including decision making, wellness, careers and employment, relationships, and self-esteem This opportunity is on Monday evenings.
10031.title: Boys and Girls Group Mentoring

10031.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10031.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 192 Jacob H. Schiff, Manhattan)

10016.description: Exciting opportunity to read storybooks to children in need with Pajama Program! Come make a positive difference in a child's life! After the reading party, volunteers will head to the local Hendriks for a Happy Hour at 12:00 p.m. 1. Fill out the nycTIES signup https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1zq8RQxWxONMXDvqNybzvXjv9UkvN0iq2i1n2CaZog1k/edit 2. Fill out the PajamaProgram signup form if it your first time volunteering with PajamaProgram http://pajamaprogram.org/volunteers/volunteer/#volunteerForm 3. Fill out the background check form if it is your first time volunteering with PajamaProgram http://www.coeusglobal.com/council_nynpcc_pajama This costs $6.95. We appreciate if volunteers can cover the cost of this themselves. Once you complete the check, you will be able to volunteer with PajamaProgram whenever you want! However, nycTIES can reimburse the cost if needed - volunteers should pay for it themselves and check off to receive reimbursement from us on their nycTIES signup form. 4. Receive confirmation from us that you are on the list. 5. Confirm your attendance with us. Volunteers should please let us know if they can no longer attend after confirmation; children are paired with volunteers, and we do not want to leave any child without a buddy! Any questions can be sent to nycties.charitymanagement@ gmail.com.
10016.title: Pajama Program Reading Party

10016.description: Thanks so much for wanting to make a difference. We are recruiting volunteers to be group facilitators for children ages 5-17 (groups are divided according to age), as well as event and fundraising helpers. Please view below for the volunteer type requirements and descriptions. The family and children group sessions are held at two Manhattan school locations, midtown and harlem. I invite you to visit our website at www.acaringhand.org to learn more about us and to acquire an application: https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/ea9db3_572250eb6e1d4899bd0837d204ffdbe9.pdf. Feel free to contact me directly at RobinGoodman@acaringhand.org for more information or to send A Caring Hand application. View our video about our group program directly at https://vimeo.com/90184263 or on our website, acaringhand.org VOLUNTEER TYPES AND REQUIREMENTS 1) GROUP FACILITATORS: Group facilators must complete an application, have an interview, and attend a 8-12 hour training. One year commitment is required to co-facilitate the child and teen groups. 11 wee group session is held 3 times per year, summer, fall and winter ( Sept - June). A monthly drop in session is held Sept-June. Attendance at a 11 week session is a minimum requirement. In certain circumstances, a commitment for the monthly groups can be accommodated. Group facilitators are assigned to weekly groups during the weekdays and evenings. The days when groups are held vary from season to season. Currently groups are held on Tuesdays and Wednesdays, and our monthly groups are held on Thursdays. Indicate your best evening availability during the week. Groups are held at two Manhattan school locations, midtown and Harlem. 2) VOLUNTEER EVENT HELP: We rely on the generous donations from individuals, corporations, and grants to fund our work. We need a strong volunteer event committe to help with all aspects of our annual gala and other fundraising activities. 3) VOLUNTEER HELPER AND FUNDRAISING: We always need extra hand on deck for various short term projects throughout the year. The projects range from stuffing envelopes and answering phones to doing outreach in th community. Certainly if you have a particular skill aor specific time you would like to help out you should let us know. We also rely on volunteers to help with A Caring Hand, The Billy Esposito Foundation fundraising activities and other board projects. WE WELCOME VOLUNTEERS WITH A RANGE OF EXPERIENCE! APPLY TODAY! Follow this direct link: https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/ea9db3_572250eb6e1d4899bd0837d204ffdbe9.pdf or visit our website at www.acaringhand.org for an application.
10016.title: Volunteer Group Facilitators and Event Help Needed!

10016.description: GO Project Spanish Translator (Saturday Volunteer) GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Spanish in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Spanish speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak Spanish. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.

We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. 10014.title: Help a Child Love to Learn: Volunteer Tutor with GO Project!

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.
